title: 105_hr1881
content: The "Tobacco Accountability Act" establishes the Tobacco Accountability Board with 5 members appointed by the Secretary of Health and Human Services. Board members serve 6-year terms and are responsible for disclosing tobacco industry documents. Tobacco manufacturers must submit all documents related to health effects, nicotine control, and marketing to children to the Tobacco Accountability Board within 3 months of the Act's enactment. This includes documents from the State of Minnesota v. Philip Morris, Inc. case. The Tobacco Accountability Board must make documents submitted by tobacco manufacturers available to the public within 6 months of the Act's enactment. Trade secrets will be protected unless disclosure is necessary for public health, allowing relevant information to be shared with other federal agencies or congressional committees. SEC. 4. INVESTIGATION AND ANNUAL REPORTS. The Board investigates tobacco industry activities related to public health annually, reporting to Congress. It discloses efforts to conceal research on health effects, mislead the public, market to children, and influence laws. The curr_chunk focuses on the adoption of laws to reduce adverse health effects or addiction caused by tobacco products. The curr_chunk discusses the requirements for tobacco manufacturers to allow a Board representative to attend their meetings and provide necessary information. The Board and its members have the authority to hold hearings, administer oaths, and enforce regulations within the tobacco industry. SEC. 7. ENFORCEMENT. Tobacco manufacturers must comply with all requirements under the Tobacco Accountability Act, allowing access to information and inspections, except where constitutional privilege applies. Any failure to comply is considered a prohibited act under the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act. SEC. 8. ADMINISTRATION. SEC. 8. ADMINISTRATION. The Chair has the authority to hire necessary staff for the Board's operation. Members receive salaries and benefits determined by the Secretary, with the Chair's salary not less than level III of the Executive Schedule. SEC. 9. DEFINITIONS. SEC. 9. DEFINITIONS. The term "Board" refers to the Tobacco Accountability Board. "Manufacture" includes manufacturing, repacking, labeling, or importing tobacco products. "Tobacco manufacturer" refers to those who manufacture tobacco products or are funded by such manufacturers.
